title: Zimbabwe: Harare, CBZ Housing Deal Takes Off
text:
Zimbabwe: Zimplats Suffer U.S $74 Million Loss 
Harare city spokesperson, Michael Chideme, recently told The Financial Gazette that the municipality had resolved to set-up a housing development vehicle jointly managed with other stakeholders in order to protect home-seekers from wanton abuse by co-operative officials and land barons. 
"We are putting final touches to it (the arrangement) now and very soon it will not be easy for co-operative officials to use member contributions on things that are not related to housing developments," Chideme said. 
He added: "The arrangement would also make it possible for housing co-operatives to get funding for their projects on the basis of their projected income and this would help speed up development." 
Under the arrangement -- which is mandatory for all housing co-operatives in the City of Harare -- all financial transactions would be conducted through CBZ Bank which will in turn work with the co-operatives, the city and the Ministry of Local Government and National Housing to ensure that the funds are used strictly for purposes related to delivery of houses to members. 
CBZ has internal expertise as it has a mortgage and property development arm. 
With all financial transactions processed via the bank, and based on the financial prospects of each co-operative or consortium of co-operatives, CBZ would be able to make advance payments for specific projects, which payment it would be able to recover as individual co-operators make their contributions. 
Last week UDCorp issued a public notice, advising members of some co-operatives in Caledonia that they could start making their payments through CBZ. 
"The City of Harare, Caledonia District Office, has started issuing Clearance Cards to individual Stand Holders of Phase 1-3," said the notice. "Each beneficiary is expected to pay a minimum development fee of US$5 000 per month into their respective co-operative CBZ Bank account detailed below. The bank will only accept payment/deposits upon production of a clearance card by each stand holders... " 
A clearance card issued by council is proof that the stand in question is within a co-operative that is recognised by the local authority. 
This means that the UDCorp arrangement would also help home-seekers to tell genuine housing co-operatives from bogus ones. 
Chideme added that the other advantage of the UDCorp arrangement was that it gave a fall-back position in the event of any problems as the home-seeker would be able to approach the city council, the bank as well the Ministry of Local Government for redress. 
Desperate home seekers lose millions of dollars every year to bogus housing co-operatives and criminals that operate as land barons. Zimbabwe
